input: DOCTOR: What brings you in today?\nPATIENT: I'm 7 years old, and I don't really know why we're here. My face feels kind of funny on one side, and I guess my mom said my cheek looks different. I don't really hurt or anything, but she said I should come see the doctor.
output:
THINKING: The patient confirms age (7 years old) and reports facial asymmetry, specifically a "funny" feeling on one side and an appearance difference in the cheek, with no pain. This introduces new clinical details about altered facial sensation or appearance and the absence of pain. No previous details are provided, so this will serve as the current full vignette.

ANSWER: A 7-year-old patient presents with a sudden onset of facial asymmetry, specifically describing a "funny" feeling on one side of the face and an appearance difference in the cheek. The patient denies pain or other associated symptoms. The concern was raised by the patient's mother, who advised seeking medical evaluation.

DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about how the facial appearance or sensation has changed over time and if you've noticed any other symptoms like weakness elsewhere, changes in vision, or ear discomfort?
PATIENT: I don’t really know... it’s maybe looked a little different, but I don’t think I feel anything weird or have other problems. Sometimes I just think my face looks different from my friends, but I don’t know if that’s new or not.
